snippet: Russian and Iranian officials dismissed the claim as a nonsensical propaganda ploy, as the Kremlin intensified military coordination with the newly emboldened forces of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Brussels, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Anne Barnard and Maher Samaan from Beirut, Lebanon; Thomas Erdbrink from Tehran; Andrew E. Kramer from Moscow; Matthew Rosenberg from Washington; and Rick Gladstone from New York.
byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: Russia and Iran scorn United States' claim that four Russian cruise missiles aimed at Syrian rebels hit rural northern Iran instead; Defense Sec Ashton B Carter sharply criticizes Russia's conduct, which reportedly includes using untested weapons systems.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Russian and Iranian officials dismissed the claim as a nonsensical propaganda ploy, as the Kremlin intensified military coordination with the newly emboldened forces of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline.print_headline: Russia Denies U.S. Claim That Missiles Aimed at Syria Hit Iran
headline.main: Russia Denies U.S. Claim That Missiles Aimed at Syria Hit Iran
